awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Examining the Role of Literacy on Predictive Processing during Spoken Language Comprehension
awd_abstract_narration:
Prediction has been proposed as a mental operation that facilitates language comprehension. That is, when listening to a sentence, a listener makes predictions about up-coming words (for instance, predicting "sugar" after hearing "I drink my coffee with cream and ..."). When people's predictions are correct, words are read faster because the person has anticipated what is coming up. Past experimental research has demonstrated that prediction in a reading task is modulated by reading skill. The interpretation of this finding is that because reading exposes people to different types of sentence structures and to a wider range of vocabulary, individuals with high reading skill have added knowledge that can be used to generate accurate predictions. One aspect that has not been considered in past literature, however, is the role of socioeconomic status (SES). This is an important variable to investigate because individuals from low SES backgrounds are also more likely to have less reading experience. Hence, it is unclear whether it is reading skill per se or socioeconomic status that impacts predictive ability. Clarifying this point is the goal of the present doctoral dissertation research study.

Drawing data from participants in a community where literacy and SES are not directly linked, two experiments will be conducted to determine the role of literacy on predictive processing during spoken language comprehension. In Experiment 1, eye movements to objects displayed on a computer screen will be recorded while participants listen to sentences where the cue to anticipation is grammatical. Experiment 2 will also employ an eye tracking technique, this time to examine how grammatical and semantic cues modulate anticipatory processes. Findings from the proposed experiments will be used to create and to offer literacy workshops for diverse and less-advantaged populations.

por.por_cntn:
When we hear someone speak or read a sentence, our brain doesn’t just passively wait for the next word to be uttered or to appear on a line of text. Instead, it actively tries to anticipate or predict the next word based on what has already been said. This is similar to how we make predictions in other scenarios. For example, think about watching a movie: we use the story so far to guess what the next scene might be. Another way to understand this is to think about doing a jigsaw puzzle. As you place more pieces together, you get a clearer sense of the picture, so when you pick up a new piece, you can make a good guess about where it might fit. Our brain works in a similar way: it uses the “pieces” it already has—that is, the words we have heard so far—to predict the next “piece” of the conversation. In psycholinguistics, this process is referred to as prediction or anticipation, and has been proposed as a mental operation that facilitates language comprehension. Prediction is important because it makes language processing faster and more efficient. Why is this so? By anticipating what is coming next, our brain can focus more on understanding and less on decoding every single word or sound. It’s like driving home: we can get ready to turn the steering wheel left because we know that a left turn is coming up even before we see it.

Past lab-based studies have shown that literacy skill—the ability to read and write—affects prediction. Because reading exposes people to different types of sentences and to a wider range of vocabulary, individuals with high reading skill may have additional knowledge that can be used to generate more accurate predictions. However, one aspect that has not been consistently considered is the role of socioeconomic status (SES). This is an important variable because individuals from low-SES are also more likely to have less reading experience. Hence, it is unclear whether it is literacy skill per se or SES that impacts predictive ability. To address this question, this project focused on adults with different literacy levels who shared the same SES background. The participants were native Spanish speakers from San Basilio de Palenque, an Afro-Colombian village where all residents live under similar economic conditions. This unique setting allowed us to isolate literacy as a variable while keeping SES constant.

Two studies were conducted to determine the role of literacy on prediction while participants listened to spoken sentences in Spanish. The results revealed that individuals with higher and lower literacy levels were equally able to predict upcoming information at the earliest possible moment. This finding challenges previous assumptions that literacy alone impacts predictive processing and suggests that the effect of literacy disappears when individuals are matched in terms of SES. It also supports the idea that, in everyday conversations, speakers rely on a set of language skills which are not dependent on one’s ability to read or write to allow for effective communication in real-world settings.

The results from this dissertation raise public awareness of the importance of linguistic diversity in language science. By combining lab and field-based research in Latin America to address novel questions about literacy, it expanded the scope of training and participation. In addition, most of what we know about how humans understand language is based on findings from a small sample of the world’s languages, and is largely based on college-aged participants. This project extended the findings to non-college educated individuals in order to assess the validity of theories of language comprehension. By focusing on low-income Afro-Colombian speakers with a range of literacy skills and on the underrepresented variety of Palenquero Spanish, this research project not only provides a better understanding of the role of literacy on predictive processing but also advocates for the legitimization and appreciation of linguistic diversity, advocating for more inclusive and representative research paradigms.
